Award.AwardTitle: Nanomanufacturing of Activated Carbon Nanosphere-Based Supercapacitors from Industrial Biomass Waste

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
There is a strong need for energy storage devices with high capacitance, high energy and high power density. These energy storage devices are required in the development of electric-based transportation and bioengineering for reducing the emissions of greenhouse gases, including carbon dioxide, methane, and nitrous oxide. Electrochemical supercapacitors, which are mostly based on carbon materials, can have much faster charging rates and longer life-times than lithium-ion batteries and can deliver clean and efficient power. The energy density of electrochemical supercapacitors can be increased significantly via the increase in the contact of active materials with electrolyte. This project involve researches in several disciplines, including nanomanufacturing, energy storage, electrochemistry, modeling and simulation. It will lead to the advancement of the processing technology for the fabrication of a class of energy materials with significantly improved electrical-chemical-mechanical properties, help grow the engineering workforce, and enhance U.S. competitiveness and leadership in the areas of energy and transportation. The research results will also provide a better understanding of the effects of electrochemical cycling on the mechanical behavior of materials on the microscale.

The ability to produce high performance energy storage devices promises to have a significant impact on various applications, including automobiles, portable electronics, photonics, and bioengineering. This research will synthesize activated carbon nanospheres (ACNs) and carbon nanosphere-based composites from industrial biomass waste derivatives (e.g. bourbon stillage) for applications in electrochemical double layer capacitors, and investigate the effect of electrochemical cycling on the characteristics of the ACNs, including microstructure, surface morphology, and chemical composition. Electrochemical indentation system will be developed for in situ characterization of the mechanical behavior of the ACNs during electrochemical cycling. Numerical modeling of the mechanical response of the ACNs under the action of electrochemical cycling will be developed to investigate the coupling effect between electrokinetic flow and the diffusion of ions on the structural durability of electrochemical double layer capacitors to help design better ACN-based supercapacitors with higher energy capacity and longer durability.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ability to produce energy storage devices of high capacity/capacitance, high energy and power density from sustainable sources, such as biomass and biowaste, promises to have a significant impact on various applications, including automobiles, flexible electronics, photonics, and bioengineering. Activated carbons exhibit unique properties and show promising performance in energy storage devices with high capacity/capacitance, high energy and power density, etc. Using biomasses of xylose, fructose, soybean residual and potato mash, activated carbons of different morphologies, including nanospheres, submicron spheres, layer structure, hierarchical structure with a two-level network and muffin-like structure have been successfully produced via hydrothermal carbonization and physical or chemical activation. The geometrical shapes and specific surface area of the activated carbons are dependent on the processing conditions, including the precursor solution, pH value, and temperatures for hydrothermal carbonization and physical or chemical activation. Applying an intermediate annealing at a temperature in a range of 400 to 500 ?C makes it possible to maintain the geometrical shape of the biomass-derived biochar after physical or chemical activation at high temperature. The electrochemical performance of the two-electrode symmetrical supercapacitors, which use the prepared activated carbons as electrode material, is dependent on the geometrical shape of the activated carbons. Activated carbons of slit-like structures, such as multilayer graphene, are preferable for supercapacitors, which can exhibit much high energy storage per unit mass of the activated carbon. Applying compressive stress onto the two-electrode symmetrical supercapacitors causes the compaction of the electrode materials and increases the mechanical rigidity of the associated electrodes. The compaction of the electrode materials can lead to significant increases of the specific capacitance of the symmetrical supercapacitors and the nominal diffusivity of electrolyte ions in the electrode materials and deceases of both internal resistance and contact resistances between electrode materials and between electrode material and current collectors. Such an approach opens a new avenue to improve the performance and long-term stability of carbon-based supercapacitors.

Three female Ph.D. students have been trained in the highly interdisciplinary research, including materials synthesis, electrochemical characterization and chemomechanical interaction. Two of them have succeeded to defend their Ph.D. theses. One is expected to graduate in the Fall of 2021. Three undergraduate students have been trained on microindentation, hydrothermal carbonization and microbial electrochemistry. One of them is pursuing graduate study in the chemical program of the Department of Chemical and Materials Engineering, University of Kentucky.
